description: Attested since the 1500s in the sense "indulged child" and since the 1530s in the sense "animal companion". From Scots and dialectal Northern English, of unclear origin. Perhaps a back-formation of petty, pety (“little, small”), a term formerly used to describe children and animals (e.g. pet lambs). Alternatively, perhaps a borrowing of Scottish Gaelic peata, from Middle Irish petta, peta (“pet, lap-dog”), of uncertain (possibly pre-Indo-European substrate) origin. Compare peat (“pet, darling, woman”).
The verb is derived from the noun.

entries.meaning: Favourite; cherished; the focus of one's (usually positive) attention.
examples: The professor seemed offended by the criticism of her pet theory.

entries.meaning: Kept or treated as a pet.
An animal kept as a companion.
(by extension) Something kept as a companion, including inanimate objects. (pet rock, pet plant, etc.)
One who is excessively loyal to a superior and receives preferential treatment.
Any person or animal especially cherished and indulged; a darling.
examples: the love of cronies, pets, and favourites

verbs.description: pet (third-person singular simple present pets, present participle petting, simple past and past participle petted or (nonstandard) pet)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, informal) To stroke or fondle (another person) amorously.
(dated, transitive) To treat as a pet; to fondle; to indulge.
examples: His daughter was petted and spoiled.

entries.meaning: (archaic, intransitive) To be peevish; to sulk.
examples: He sure is queasie stomach't that must pet, and puke, at such a trivial circumstance

entries.meaning: A fit of petulance, a sulk, arising from the impression that one has been offended or slighted.
examples: There was something ludicrous, even more, unbecoming a gentleman, in leaving a friend's house in a pet, with the host's reproaches sounding in his ears, to be matched only by the bitterness of the guest's sneering retorts.

entries.meaning: (Ireland, Tyneside) A term of endearment usually applied to women and children.
